A. S. C. E. MAKING PLANS
FOR NEXT MEETING
The Hopkins Student Chapter
of the American Society of Civil
Engineers is laying elaborate plans
for its next meeting and smoker,
which will be held during the latter part of this month. A committee, consisting of Walter H. Sommerville, '23, chairman; Ed Watson, '24, and Benj. Rome, '25, were
appointed by President Wills to obtain a speaker and to provide entertainment and refreshments for
the smoker. The last affair of the
society, held a few weeks ago, was
declared by all present to be one
of the best ever given by the organization.
The emblems of the society, consisting of a maroon shield engraved
in gold on a circular white background, which were originally in-

Every year Mr 'O'Brien makes a survey of the
fiction published by American magazines, and
his appraisal is generally accepted as authoritative by students of literature. The best of
the stories selected by Mr O'Brien are annually
republished in book form.

THE DIAL was first awarded the rating of 100%
in 1920, at the end of its first year as a magazine of art and letters. Again in 1921 THE DIAL
headed Mr O'Brien's list, and now in 1922,
for the third consecutive year, THE DIAL has
achieved the highest rating in Mr O'Brien's
classification.
This record is particularly significant in view

Our business is one which calls for an investment consisting of time and effort.
It is the largest, most profitable business in the world. We are going to invest
our time in order to train a selected class of students so that they will b t able to
convert their spare time into money.
This course will be free of any cost to the students selected. It will be arranged
so as not to conflict with other work and studies. The successful student will
find himself equipped to enjoy a clean, profitable vocation during the spring
and summer months. Then, too, every effort expended during your spare time
and the summer months will multiply and form the nucleus of your income in
the future.

A. S. C. E. MAKING PLANS
FOR NEXT MEETING
The Hopkins Student Chapter
of the American Society of Civil
Engineers is laying elaborate plans
for its next meeting and smoker,
which will be held during the latter part of this month. A committee, consisting of Walter H. Sommerville, '23, chairman; Ed Watson, '24, and Benj. Rome, '25, were
appointed by President Wills to obtain a speaker and to provide entertainment and refreshments for
the smoker. The last affair of the
society, held a few weeks ago, was
declared by all present to be one
of the best ever given by the organization.
The emblems of the society, consisting of a maroon shield engraved
in gold on a circular white background, which were originally in-

Every year Mr 'O'Brien makes a survey of the
fiction published by American magazines, and
his appraisal is generally accepted as authoritative by students of literature. The best of
the stories selected by Mr O'Brien are annually
republished in book form.

THE DIAL was first awarded the rating of 100%
in 1920, at the end of its first year as a magazine of art and letters. Again in 1921 THE DIAL
headed Mr O'Brien's list, and now in 1922,
for the third consecutive year, THE DIAL has
achieved the highest rating in Mr O'Brien's
classification.
This record is particularly significant in view
of the fact that Mr O'Brien selects for his percentage ratings only stories of unusual merit
and distinction. THE DIAL'S record of 100%
means, therefore, that since 1920 it has not
published a single mediocre story.

Our business is one which calls for an investment consisting of time and effort.
It is the largest, most profitable business in the world. We are going to invest
our time in order to train a selected class of students so that they will b t able to
convert their spare time into money.
This course will be free of any cost to the students selected. It will be arranged
so as not to conflict with other work and studies. The successful student will
find himself equipped to enjoy a clean, profitable vocation during the spring
and summer months. Then, too, every effort expended during your spare time
and the summer months will multiply and form the nucleus of your income in
the future.
